title: configure.ac: Fix _FORTIFY_SOURCE macro
body:
This commit fixes the mistake in the `_FORTIFY_SOURCE` macro where it was not prefixed with underscore while it has to be (see e.g. https://github.com/search?q=repo%3Abminor%2Fglibc%20FORTIFY_SOURCE&type=code).

Additionally, to make this macro add extra security, one has to enable optimizations. I am not sure if the configure enables them, but it is worth double checking that as well.

Overall, I would recommend using `-D_FORTIFY_SOURCE=3` with  `-O2` or `-O3`. (The fortify source level 3 was added recently and you can read more about it here: https://developers.redhat.com/blog/2021/04/16/broadening-compiler-checks-for-buffer-overflows-in-_fortify_source).

You can also see the result of the correct vs incorrect macro along with optimizations and no optimizations on this screenshot ([source](https://godbolt.org/#z:OYLghAFBqd5QCxAYwPYBMCmBRdBLAF1QCcAaPECAMzwBtMA7AQwFtMQByARg9KtQYEAysib0QXACx8BBAKoBnTAAUAHpwAMvAFYTStJg1DIApACYAQuYukl9ZATwDKjdAGFUtAK4sGIM6SuADJ4DJgAcj4ARpjEIABspAAOqAqETgwe3r7%2ByanpAiFhkSwxcYl2mA4ZQgRMxARZPn4BldUCtfUERRHRsQm2dQ1NOa1D3aG9pf3xAJS2qF7EyOwc5gDMocjeWADUJutuCgTEocAAdAgH2CYaAIK3d6EEuyxMoRDPu8ik3wj1ACpdvVgAA3EwAVisEIAIrN9gB2Kz3XZ/eq7KJeKiQixcDSQmEHZF3VHHZZJACeEExVF%2BIPBUPxsNmRMeJgRMI481onAhvD8HC0pFQnDc1msuwUi2WmH2ZnWPFIBE0XPmAGsJPFzhD1gAOLgKgCc8TMZmNkkN%2Bk4kn5KuFnF4ChAGiVKvmcFgMCgXogSDQLCSdFi5Eo/sD9DiwC4ptIWFBeBWADU8JgAO4AeSSjE4ipotAIsSd1LtUVC9QpOd4/rYgnTDFoFcFvCwbyM4ibsbwxCqjlBmCdHcwqiqXgLduemB5HdoeCixHLHiwdpOeBYlfmVAMwAUybTmez3F4/EEIjE7CkMkEihU6g7umkBiMKHFln0s6dkHmqCSjgEA4AtDCAD6ABi6YAEoACoAJIgQAmkBQjpnI4FuDc6wwlwuz/umiptL%2BfgQK4Ix%2BFwgQMOgPQlGUegpGkBEkbR%2BQEVRfRxGR%2BE1OMjEcZOPZcV0rHTOxgxdDxokNEJNFcPMUpLCsEjcrytodiKHC7KourxP%2B8SSLswDIMguzRucZi7BAuCECQcoKrMvDKk2szzAgmBMFgcQQOqIAQi6U42qQa7rFqhoaPEXC6VwUi6ZI8TGqQApCmpjrOq6jmkB6iAoKgAZBmQFAQGGuUgFGMZxgmmC7hmWYCrmdAFsQRZRCWZbEI2irVowBB1g2dotoYwDtkK%2BDdtUfYDkKQ4jmOHYTlOQoznOC4YKsQormuh4bluO4plVB65rIp7iBex7yEoah2roEL6P1z6WNYb5RB%2BnnCj%2BGQAcBYFQbBCFIShaEHJh2HpkKnHOERFHicEkzUf0ZF0QUmSeM0TH0RkUmw7YfHtAwnTDEjOS8fYBG4xMxRsXoxxifjpESaTUzSbJ0oKTJVocHy8V2mpGlaTpekGUZJlmRZ%2BBEMQNkyfZbrOa57mUEpHD%2BWuZrnAi8QaD5ZgQhCZgaGYXCGoa6wc6pDq2ClDlaO6Pp%%2B2akHNqVZso1i6hHXq0d%2BqDXjiNXs/Zk7DlTtNIUs1s6zlzhSfOy5TjrR4JtJg25S6UMPJeYQogjrV1kLXW8QpdBkUbrdKwr5W7wHbgRd6oEIK9x%2BgPf6GEzI4TMI6MeGQJ7uC3uRSiK855w2YhkRePjCieOkpjImAlD7I23sTcYe8KabyPjEwSgTYYXxlIpVmN9OacG5o/PmL9BYfxFtZDYEtf7wMQb5a0vBApagRIaMwkhta6nWBoLguotK6kgXfaB5s3TpWtllXB9tQyEKdsQ2MpDyoKL2t7fMvtiwBxagw0OTDOrdUjs2dhbZ07DUTrwwc/C07jkznNXgOclpLg7IXDaxc5HbQoVM5RlcJDqKvGdLROhch6NMHdQx75jEvVMV3D6Fjvr9z%2BkPOxwNHEhLBsRNxM96YYyXr4txSKAmzyCaDHGsTwnBPXlihJ6KMYn3EifaJLM5IpJZlOdJJt1IP15s/AWb8haf0KfKYpcCnKkBcm5foz0/KVP8Lqc4xp4i6hirrLWXAEQQnCh0%2B06CzawJ6dg/pds8pDIGZGF2YyyEVQ9oo2qMyaFzKFIHcsIcw4sJ6h2PqmzeoJ1Grsia%2BzBG8GEdOURZyC5SKLpuG5kyvYPNUVX title: about queues
body:
Hi all,
I had a few questions regarding how to use Torque scheduler. Assume [if required] that we have the required permissions [admin, etc.] of a cluster.


1. How can we define a  maximum wait time for a job before execution (when it is in the queue?)

2. If a job has reached its maximum wait time (for a certain queue), can we change its current queue specified by the user in job script?

3. Can we define a parameter that does not allow users or specific jobs to be executed in a particular queue?

4. Is there a way to find out automatically the elapsed time of a certain job (by using qstat or other tools)?


Thank you very much in advance for your help.

title: Error with X11 Forwarding
body:
Users see 'could not bind local socket: Invalid argument' in their error stream when using `qsub -X`. The error originates from https://github.com/adaptivecomputing/torque/blob/8a0b748d3644dde30372ee25c4fe05bec10b2166/src/lib/Libnet/port_forwarding.c#L440

It is because the [get_local_address](https://github.com/adaptivecomputing/torque/blob/23266fe781ce41a167a0a2f312693a0ca6fedd0d/src/lib/Libnet/net_common.c#L1050)() function returns a sa_family=AF_INET struct but the loop at https://github.com/adaptivecomputing/torque/blob/8a0b748d3644dde30372ee25c4fe05bec10b2166/src/lib/Libnet/port_forwarding.c#L420-L446 will attempt to bind all types, causing bind to be called on a AF_INET6 socket with a AF_INET argument and producing the error message.

I've submitted https://github.com/adaptivecomputing/torque/pull/458 as a potential fix, but should probably be revisited so that it will work with IPv6. Note that the IPv6 limitation is one of get_local_address() and not the patch.

title: Prevent binding to mismatched AF_ type
integration problem between Torque 4 and Intel(R) MPI Library for Linux* OS, Version 2019 Update 1
body:
Hi!

I have successfully compiled and linked a program with IntelMPI and if I run it interactively or in background it runs very fast and without any problems on our new server (ProLiant DL580 Gen10, 1 node with 4 processors with 18 cores each, total 72 cores, hyperthreading disabled). If I try to submit it by Torque (version 4) strange things happen, for example:

1) if I submit 2 jobs asking each 8 cores they are both fine

2) if I submit a third job (8 cores) it is 4 times slower becasue the 8 process runs on two cores!

3) if I submit a fourth job it runs properly, but if I qdel all the four jobs, all of them disappear from qstat -a but the fourth is keeping running!

I have the feeling it is an integration problem between intelmpi and torque, so I did the following:

 export I_MPI_PIN=off
 export I_MPI_PIN_DOMAIN=socket

to run the program I did the following call of mpirun:

/opt/intel/compilers_and_libraries_2019.1.144/linux/mpi/intel64/bin/mpirun -d -rmk pbs -bootstrap pbsdsh .................

I have checked and PBS_ENVIRONMENT is properly set to PBS_BATCH

Also torque configuration is apparently correct, the file

/var/lib/torque/server_priv/nodes contains the following line:

dscfbeta1.units.it np=72 num_node_boards=1

This is a severe problem for me, since the machine is shared so we do need a scheduler like torque (pbs) to run jobs compiled and linked to intelmpi. Any help suggestion is welcome!

thank you in advance

Mauro

title: Always use primary group for initgroups
body:
When users are not members of their primary group[1], initgroups(3) being called with the group listed in the group_list parameter causes the primary group to be missing in supplemental group list for the launched job. 

This change will cause init_groups to always call initgroups(3) with the user's primary group so that it will continue to exist later on when setgid is called with the group from the group_list. 

Redacted example:
```
[user@login ~] # groups
primarygrp secondarygrp

# Unpatched node:
[user@login ~] # qsub -I -W group_list=secondarygrp
[user@compute ~] groups
secondarygrp

# Patched node:
[user@login ~] # qsub -I -W group_list=secondarygrp
[user@compute ~] groups
secondarygrp primarygrp
```

[1] Happens when the user's entry in LDAP assigns them to a group, but they aren't added to the group member list.

title: Trim down on zeros in PCI domain for sysfs
body:
NVML returns `00000000` as PCI domain while sysfs uses `0000`. This patch trims the 8 zeros to 4 to read from sysfs.

For example, on our system NVML returned: `00000000:82:00.0` while the sysfs path was `0000:82:00.0`.

I'm not entirely sure if this is the right approach. Maybe first try to read the full path and only then fall back to the one with the trimmed zeros?

Please backport to 6.1.2.

title: /etc/profile.d/torque.csh error on CentOS 7
body:
Hi all,

The package file moab-torque-client-6.1.1.1-1.el7.x86_64.rpm (provided by Adaptive as part of MOAB) contains the file /etc/profile.d/torque.csh with these contents when installed:

test -d ${_bindir} && setenv PATH /usr/local/bin:${PATH}
test `id -u` = 0 && test-d ${_sbindir} && setenv PATH /usr/local/sbin:${PATH}

Off course, these dirs "_bindir" and "_sbindir" respectively, so this fails.

Moreover, when you want to start "csh" (say, from bash), you get:

$ csh
_bindir: Undefined variable.

As a side effect, running csh-scripts using "csh -e ./script.csh", the script returns error 1 and never runs.

-- Regards,

Franky

title: Fix GPU with cgroups devices
body:
If you build torque with GPU support and cgroups, it doesn't work: the whitelisting of devices in cgroups is not done correctly. 

The core of the problem is the difference between `initialize_hwloc_topology` and `cg_initialize_hwloc_topology`. The code assumes that it is sufficient to call just one of them which is not true: the function `read_all_devices` is only called from the `cg_initialize_hwloc_topology`. I've merged both functions together and the difference between both are handled by macro's. I'm not sure what the idea was to duplicate this function? Copy&pasting code like that is only going to give problems, as this issue shows.

Please backport this to the 6.1.1.1.

title: builds > 5.1.2 failing
body:
I am attempting to upgrade a cluster running Debian stable ('stretch') from TORQUE 5.1.2 to a more recent version. On my current head node I am able to compile 5.1.2 with DRMAA support without problems, but attempts to build 5.1.3 or 6.1.1.1 fail when compiling DRMAA libraries with a bunch of "redefinition" errors of the sort

```
In file included from /usr/include/c++/6/bits/stl_algobase.h:61:0,                                                                                                                          
                 from /usr/include/c++/6/bits/char_traits.h:39,                                                                                                                                 
                 from /usr/include/c++/6/string:40,                                                                                                                                                  
                 from ../../../src/include/attribute.h:76,
                 from ../../../src/include/lib_ifl.h:4,
                 from submit.c:39:
/usr/include/c++/6/bits/cpp_type_traits.h:205:12: error: redefinition of ‘struct std::__is_integer<int>’
```
These seem to occur when compiling `src/drmaa/src/session.c` and `src/drmaa/src/submit.c`. In comparing these files between 5.1.2 and 5.1.3, it seems the main difference is the include statement for `lib_ifl.h`. If I remove these includes everything builds okay, but I'm unsure of whether this will affect functionality of the DRMAA libs.

I tried to post this to the `torqueusers` mailing list, but for some reason the form to join isn't working for me right now, so I'm posting here in case someone can provide insight or has seen this issue before.

title: Incorrectly formated resource request crashes pbs_server

#PBS -l walltime=24:00:00,nodes=1,ppn=4,mem=30gb

pbs_server crashes consistently when jobs are submitted with this resource request.

title: Reset fromlen before each accept() call
body: Accept() will only write fromlen bytes to the buffer it is given, but will then set fromlen to the number of bytes it wanted to write. This causes subsequent calls to write past the from buffer onto stack variables, noticeably the n loop counter which causes a segfault. Fix resets fromlen before each accept() call.

title: Node names that start with a number not accepted
body:
My hostnames begin with numbers (e.g. 0xxx.xxx), and this is causing the pbs_server to fail with errors similar to this:
PBS_Server[6531]: LOG_ERROR::parse_node_name, token "0xxx.xxx" doesn't start with alpha on line 1

The problem is in torque/src/server/node_func.c, in the parse_node_name function, where numeric node names are rejected for non-Cray systems. I know that I can simply change my hostnames. However, RFC1123 (https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc1123#page-13) explicitly allows numeric hostnames, so the behavior seems like an error.

title: Don't drop ATTR_v when encoding attropl

title: Job dependencies not propertly tracked for jobs in routing queue
body:
If we have jobs in a routing queue waiting for slots to open up in an execution queue (due to max_user_queuable limits), and those jobs have dependencies on jobs already in the execution queue, then the job may get rejected when it does finally route if one or more of the jobs it depends on have already executed and completed. upon routing, job is immediately rejected: "Job rejected by all possible destinations (check syntax, queue resources, ...)"

We need job dependencies to be tracked properly for jobs in routing queues.

title: authenticate_user;Hosts do not match regularly found in server log
body:
We're running torque 4.2.10 and we're seeing communication failures at sporadic intervals. The server log shows the following type of error:

```
02/28/2017 01:14:19;0004;PBS_Server.15205;Svr;authenticate_user;Hosts do not match: Requested host korf.nikhef.nl: credential host: stremsel.nikhef.nl
```
There is no rhyme or rhythm found in the names of the hosts; they could be hosts from which jobs are submitted, the torque server itself or any one of the worker nodes.

We know that this error is reproducible in a consistent manner when the clock on one of the nodes is wrong; somehow the message is signed (by trqauthd?) with a timestamp, causing a mismatch in the identity/credential checking, but we've since made sure all our hosts are using ntp.

I have had a sidelong glance at the code where the checks are done, but I found the caching algorithm hard to understand.

title: Job Variable_List dropped if qsub does not submit on first try
body:
A job's "Variable_List" attribute appears to get dropped if an attempt at job submission does not go through on the first try.  This is likely to not be isolated to qsub, but that is the only way I have attempted to demonstrate it.

qsub makes multiple attempts at job submission in cmds/qsub_functions.c main_func().  I tripped upon this particular issue when submitting a job with a dependency that sent back a PBSE_BADDEPEND on first try but then succeeded once alternate_dependency was substituted in.

My amateur digging has led me to src/lib/Libifl/env_attropl_hash.c build_var_list(), where I can see that ATTR_v is deleted from the hash.  It's not 100% clear why this is done, other than I noticed that the ATTR_v is sent last in encode_DIS_attropl_hash() and dropping ATTR_v would prevent it from being sent twice.  If that is the case a simple if check in enc_DIS_attropl_hash_single() might be better than deleting from the hash table and losing state in between submission attempts.

title: Let pbstop parser read consecutive index jobs
body:
The pbstop contrib tool parses the output of 'qmgr -l -n' and
uses the information to display a grid of the cluster which shows
where jobs are running.

It seems that starting with commit 1573753 the format of the job
list returned by pbsnodes/qmgr changed so that multiple core jobs
was condensed and this borke the pbstop parsing algorithm. This is
a simple patch that will recognize the new format.

The format for the "jobs" attribute of a node was:
0/JOB1, 1/JOB1, 2/JOB1, 3/JOB2

Now it is:
0-2/JOB1, 3/JOB2

I wasn't able to test the modPBS routine but the format should be the same.

title: Job Routing Order
body:
We are experimenting with routing queues to allow us to submit large number of jobs in excess of our "max_user_queable" limit on our execution queues.  Some of these jobs have dependencies on each other. 

During experimentation I found that once our max_user_queuable" limit was hit in the destination execution queue,  jobs from the routing queue would start getting routed in reverse order as slots opened up in the execution queue.  So if I had 1000 jobs waiting in the routing queue, as soon as a slot opened up the 1000th job would get moved to the execution node and not the 1st.  (jobs that failed to route immediately were basically being routed LIFO instead of FIFO as slots opened up).

I ran into the problem where a job that depended on a previously submitted job would get routed before the job it had a dependency on.  Eventually my max_user_queueable limit was filled with jobs waiting on jobs that were still in the routing queue,  and none of my jobs could run. 

Jobs held up in the routing queue should get routed in a FIFO order as slots become available in the execution queue. 

This test was done with Torque 6.0.1 and Moab 9.0.1

Debian enables lock elision in libc by default. On HLE enabled CPUs ```pthread_mutex_unlock``` is handled through ```__lll_unlock_elision```. This low level unlocking function does not accept unlocking of free mutexes. From what I've read so far, other unlocking functions seemed to accept that.

Line 29 of ```elision_unlock.c``` in libc sources has a comment:
```
26  /* When the lock was free we're in a transaction.
27     When you crash here you unlocked a free lock.  */
28  if (*lock == 0)
29    _xend();
```

body: Testing JIRA syncing.

title: I have updated the configure logic to reject anything other than the …
body:
…PMIx v1.1.5 (or something further along the v1 series, should we release something) as that is the only release out there today. Future releases can be supported with the appropriate #if checks for PMIX_VERSION in the code.

I found a race condition in the PMIx integration that registers nspaces and clients. The PMIx APIs for that purpose are non-blocking, but they must complete prior to you fork/exec'ing any local clients. Otherwise, a connection request that arrives at the PMIx server prior to completing the registration functions will be rejected.

I don't know your threading model enough to figure out how to implement the wait function, so I left some comments (they start with "RHC" so you can search for them) that explain what needs to be done. Hopefully, those will be clear enough to get you thru the problem. If not, feel free to holler.

title: qalter on array job
body:
When you run `qalter` on a job within a array: `qalter -l nodes=1:ppn=2 1000[1]`, this will change all jobs within the array. This is not the behaviour we expected.
- `qalter -l nodes=1:ppn=2 1000` should change all jobs within the array.
- `qalter -l nodes=1:ppn=2 -t 1 1000` should change a single job within the array.
- `qalter -l nodes=1:ppn=2  1000[1]` should either give an error or change a single job within the array.

Feature request: set hierarchical memory limits in cgroups
body:
Hi,

It would be nice to have memory cgroup limits set on the torque cgroup, not just on the job cgroup(s). This would ensure the hierarchy (use_hierarchy is set to 1) would honour these limits.

The limits could be set tot what is actually available for the jobs, so e.g., RAM - reserved kernel memory - reserved other stuff (like the GPFS page pool), etc. The mewsw limit could be set to this plus the available swap space.

The underlying idea is to have the torque cgroup kill tasks, before OOM killer comes by.

-- Andy

title: delete_job_files with $thread_unlink_calls may fail on locked memory
body:
I've turned on $thread_unlink_calls in torque 4.2.10 and found that the transient job directories were not removed.

Through some debugging I discovered that the mom locks itself into main memory (probably a good idea) through memlock; but the worker threads that take care of the deletion change user identity to the owner of the job. The `ulimit -l` is 64kB, but for root it's not enforced. However, after the identity switch it _is_ enforced and the first time `malloc()` tries to `brk()` or `mmap()` it will fail with EAGAIN because too much memory is locked already.

The POSIX standard for threads dictates that all threads should change user id, so it seems best to relegate the deletion of worker directories to a subprocess with a `fork()` rather than using a thread...

For now we've worked around the limitation by increasing the limit on locked memory.

title: Unexpected array dependency behaviour
body:
It seems, to me and to our group, that after(not)okarray is acts differently to after(not)ok.

I received a response on this issue via the torque users mailing list (thanks, David), but am still not quite clear whether there is anything I'm doing wrong.

I'll show the example that I am using in full. The submitting script is as
follows:

```
dn=`dirname $0`

jid=`qsub -t 0-3 ${dn}/fiveSecsSleep.sh`
qsub -W depend=afternotokarray:${jid%%.headnode01} -F ${jid}
/scratch/cwirth/testing/afternotok/checkErrors.sh
qsub -W depend=afterokarray:${jid%%.headnode01} -N ifOK
${dn}/fiveSecsSleep.sh
```

and fiveSecsSleep.sh is as follows:

```
#PBS -N five
#PBS -o /scratch/cwirth/testing/afternotok/log/fiveSecOut
#PBS -e /scratch/cwirth/testing/afternotok/log/fiveSecErr

sleep 5

exit 0
```

When I run the submitting script, shortly after the array job has
completed, all with exit code 0, qstat shows this:

```
576468[0].headnode01       five-0           cwirth          00:00:00 C
bioinf.q
576468[1].headnode01       five-1           cwirth          00:00:00 C
bioinf.q
576468[2].headnode01       five-2           cwirth          00:00:00 C
bioinf.q
576468[3].headnode01       five-3           cwirth          00:00:00 C
bioinf.q
576469.headnode01          check            cwirth                 0 H
bioinf.q
576470.headnode01          ifOK             cwirth          00:00:00 C
bioinf.q
```

Then, once the completed jobs have been removed from the queue, it still
shows this:

```
576469.headnode01          check            cwirth                 0 H
bioinf.q
```

If I change the final line in fiveSecsSleep.sh from Œexit 0¹ to Œexit 1¹,
then run the submitting script, I get the inverse.

While running, qstat says:

```
576472[0].headnode01       five-0           cwirth                 0 R
bioinf.q
576472[1].headnode01       five-1           cwirth                 0 R
bioinf.q
576472[2].headnode01       five-2           cwirth                 0 R
bioinf.q
576472[3].headnode01       five-3           cwirth                 0 R
bioinf.q
576473.headnode01          check            cwirth                 0 H
bioinf.q
576474.headnode01          ifOK             cwirth                 0 H
bioinf.q
```

Shortly followed by:

```
576472[0].headnode01       five-0           cwirth          00:00:00 C
bioinf.q
576472[1].headnode01       five-1           cwirth          00:00:00 C
bioinf.q
576472[2].headnode01       five-2           cwirth          00:00:00 C
bioinf.q
576472[3].headnode01       five-3           cwirth          00:00:00 C
bioinf.q
576473.headnode01          check            cwirth          00:00:00 C
bioinf.q
576474.headnode01          ifOK             cwirth                 0 H
bioinf.q
```

And finally (and indefinitely):

```
576474.headnode01          ifOK             cwirth                 0 H
bioinf.q
```

Of course, this does mean that the correct jobs are being run when they
are supposed to be, which is the most important thing. However, it still
means that the jobs that DON¹T run (and shouldn¹t) are held in the queue
perpetually. In the equivalent case for afterok or afternotok, jobs are
removed from the queue when it becomes clear that their prerequisite
condition has not been, and will not be, met. This behaviour would be
preferable for me.

For completeness, it appears we are on the following version:

Version: 5.1.2
Commit: f498aba075f61bb7ab07caaebeaa82f387b2b1fb

title: Directory permissions are not created correctly on the (re-created) cgroup dirs
body:
- the first time the cgroup subdirs are created, the permissions are 0755 (correct)
- remove e.g., /sys/fs/cgroup/memory/torque on the node and a pbs_mom thread will recreate them, but with incorrect permissions 0700 (incorrect), as the unmake has been set at that time.
- this happens in 6.0-dev commit f90340b

title: The preq variable passed to svr_strtjob2 is the wrong request.
body:
It should have been the AsyrunJob request but it is now the CopyFiles request to stage the
files to the mom; and that request has been done and dealt with. Usually the
ack later on to this request will not go through, as the file descriptor to
which it was associated is already closed, but in some cases the fd has been
reopened to start more jobs on the same worker node. In that case the ack
is misinterpreted as a Connect request by the mom and the job commit will not
go through, leaving jobs in a strange state. The fix in this commit mitigates
the problem by preventing the ack from being sent.

For a longer explaination see the [wiki page](https://github.com/dvandok/torque/wiki/Post-mortem-of-a-bug) I wrote.

title: 4.2 dev fixcrash
body:
Started taking 4.2.10 into production, and immediately ran into trouble. For some reason every now and again there is a miscommunication between the server and the mom which causes a failure to start a job. This happens after the files are already staged in. Due to the handling of the situation, a later attempt to rerun the job crashes the server.

The two commits make sure that the job is cleared of the stagedIn flag so it can be rerun, and guard against the unsafe assumption that exec_host will be set if the StagedIn flag is set.

title: torque jobs cannot depend on both array and non-array jobs
body:
Something like:

```
#PBS -W depend=afterok:35487338.gpc-sched-ib0:35487339.gpc-sched-ib0:35487341.gpc-sched-ib0:35487344.gpc-sched-ib0  -W depend=afterokarray:35487333[].gpc-sched-ib0:35487334[].gpc-sched-ib0:35487336[].gpc-sched-ib0:35487337[].gpc-sched-ib0
```

Is not currently allowed, as per @dbeer 
From the mailing list:

> I believe the currently we do not allow the mixing of array dependencies and regular dependencies. We would need to modify the code to allow this. This seems like a reasonable thing to allow, but I believe the code is currently implemented to disallow mixing.

title: qstat -x returns no output when no jobs are present, breaks XML parsing
body:
I have been playing with the XML outputs of SGE and Torque and noticed that I can’t blindly grab the output of `qstat -x` and parse it, because if there’s no jobs, its output is empty.

In comparison, SGE gives a properly formatted XML document:

```
> qstat -xml
<?xml version='1.0'?>
<job_info  xmlns:xsd="http://arc.liv.ac.uk/repos/darcs/sge/source/dist/util/resources/schemas/qstat/qstat.xsd">
  <queue_info>
  </queue_info>
  <job_info>
  </job_info>
</job_info>
```

Perhaps Torque should also dump an empty document that’s parsable?

Reply from @dbeer on mailing list

> Yes, that would probably be proper. I've logged an internal bug for this. If you'd like to be able to track it externally, please log an issue on our github page.

title: Support for handling (g)zipped log files by tracejob
body:
Currently, trace job does not consider log files that have been (g)zipped. The reason for the zipping is pretty straightforward: it saves a huge amount of space. The downside is that trace job does not consider them when looking up information about a job.

Would it be possible to use e.g., zlib to transparently handle files that have been compressed?

we need proper escaping of the commandline passed to submitfilter, or better yet, pass the commandline args as an array.

title: qsub -d <path> with commas in <path> fails
body:
The following is a summary of torqueusers [thread `qsub -d <path> with commas in <path> fails`](http://www.supercluster.org/pipermail/torqueusers/2016-March/018585.html) (2016-03-20):
# Problem

`qsub -d <path>` does not work for paths with commas. When commas are used the job is submitted but silently drops everything following and including the comma.

Example:

``` sh
mkdir $HOME/foo $HOME/foo,bar
echo 'pwd; echo PBS_O_WORKDIR=$PBS_O_WORKDIR' | qsub -j oe -d $HOME/foo,bar
```

The working directory is simply set to `$HOME/foo` (note that `,bar` is dropped);

``` sh
$ more foo/STDIN.o*
foo/STDIN.o313477:
/home/henrik/foo
PBS_O_WORKDIR=/home/henrik/foo
```
# Failed workarounds

I get identical results when (single or double) quoting the path or escaping the comma;

``` sh
qsub -d "$HOME/foo,bar"
qsub -d '/home/henrik/foo,bar'
qsub -d $HOME/foo\,bar
```

Likewise when trying to pass `<path>` via an environment variable, e.g.

``` sh
wdir=$HOME/foo,bar
echo 'pwd; echo PBS_O_WORKDIR=$PBS_O_WORKDIR' | qsub -j oe -d $wdir
```

Escaping the quotation marks in bash gives the following (self-explanatory) error:

``` sh
$ echo 'pwd; echo PBS_O_WORKDIR=$PBS_O_WORKDIR' | qsub -j oe -d \"$HOME/foo,bar\"
[qsub: cannot chdir to '"/home/henrik/foo,bar"' errno: 2 (No such file or directory)]
```
# Partly working workaround

If I try to use soft links to create a path without commas, it partly works, e.g.

``` sh
ln -s $HOME/foo,bar $HOME/aux
echo 'pwd; echo PBS_O_WORKDIR=$PBS_O_WORKDIR' | qsub -j oe -d $HOME/aux
```

Interestingly, the output is still written too `$HOME/foo` and `PBS_O_WORKDIR` is set accordingly, but the actual working directory is indeed `$HOME/foo,bar`, e.g.

``` sh
$ more foo/STDIN.o313710
/home/henrik/foo,bar
PBS_O_WORKDIR=/home/henrik/foo
```
# Session information

``` sh
$ qsub --version
Version: 4.2.9
Commit: a78379d06ed3c309a4a38cdaafb146fba60608dc

$ uname -a
Linux cclc01.som.ucsf.edu 2.6.32-504.12.2.el6.664g0000.x86_64 #1 SMP Wed Mar 11 14:20:51 EDT 2015 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
```

title: Mistake in the man page. down_on_error is currently true by default now.
body:
The default value for down_on_error was changed in https://github.com/adaptivecomputing/torque/commit/f33c05a014d5f0d9e1b7b7226f0ce0e02f1e79a9#diff-f41edbf0d83389af469d191a7aa5b195. This change updates the documentation to reflect that change.

On another note, is this still an experimental feature as the man page says?

title: Feature  - added server attribute to pbs_server "note_append_on_error"
body: Added server attribute to pbs_server "note_append_on_error" to allow disabling of pbs_server appending notes based on a node health check error from pbs_mom. This does not change the default functionality of pbs_server, but simply allows admins to disable this behavior if its not desired.

title: set_note_error endlessly appends notes to the node
body:
nhc (node health check) outputs to STDOUT "ERROR: some message" and has never caused any issues with torque release prior to 6.0.1. With torque 6.0.1 this is interpreted as an error to append to the note, this is not the desired or expected behavior.

Can you provide some background as to why this feature was needed? I don't want to break compatibility if this is a well documented and used feature.

I was not able to run the unit tests to verify this change doesn't break them, do you have instructions for running the unit tests?

-David

title: pbsnodes does not change the note and node state (offline,online) atomically
body:
This issue was discovered by troubleshooting a problem where occasionally some nodes were marked offline without a note by nhc. Trying to determine the root cause I noticed in the logs of nhc, the following pbsnodes output: "Error marking node nodename......" that occurred when nodes were found offline without a note.  The way pbsnodes currently works (when given -c -N) is it calls set_note first and then marknode, which both call pbs_manager_err.  The bug happens when nhc runs "pbsnodes -c -N '' nodename" and pbs_manager_err succeeds for set_note and fails for marknode, this clears the note but does not put the node back online.  The fix is for pbsnodes to set the note and node state with a single pbs_manager_err call, which means both change atomically.  nhc works by marking a node offline and setting the note to "NHC: somecheck" when a node meets an error condition and brings it back online when the condition is resolved.  nhc only clears nodes marked offline by nhc (note must start with "NHC:"), so this bug causes nhc to leave nodes offline without a note and thus leaves nodes unavailable to users even though there is no current issue on the node.

I tested this change on a small 50 node cluster and was able to verify that the issue was repeatable with the current "pbsnodes" and that this change prevented nodes from ending up in the "offline without a note" state after a pbsnodes -c -N '' nodename command.

title: Failure to set memory limits in cgroups
body:
We have an issue with the cgroup creation. This was done on 37ae8750b2e
The jobscript is

``` bash
#!/bin/bash

#PBS -q long

sleep 72h

The job will start but return immediately with code -3 (`JOB_EXEC_RETRY`) and will keep on retrying. This is caused by a failure to create the cgroups. In the node logs we find:

title: Avoid killing running jobs due to time drift when the mom restarts
body:
This is a workaround for #324.

A real fix would be to avoid the reliance on btime, instead tracking jiffies.
- added logging to track found time differences
- allow for a time difference up to 1 hour (3600 seconds).
- make sure qstat does something when run without arguments (see #322)

title: Restarting the mom kills the running job(s)
body:
We have built new RPMs to deal with the XML issue in the job scripts. However when restarting the mom on the nodes, the running jobs are (sometimes) killed.

We have reason to believe the culprit can be found in the comparison between job_start_time and session_start_time in scan_non_child_tasks (in mom_mach.c). At some point this is executed and the following comparison is made:

```
if(job_start_time == session_start_time)
  {
  found = 1;
  }
```

I think that only way to move found tasks to the exited state is by not setting found to 1. On occasions this seems to happen, but not always.

Drilling down, the time used comes from /proc/<pid>/stat, for both job_start_time and sessions_start_time, but in case of clock skew these can be different.

To force reproduction of the issue, you can force the btime values to be different, e.g., 

```
service ptpd2 stop # or ntpd 
hwclock --date 'Thu Sep 10 14:56:56 CEST 2015' --set 
hwclock -s 
```

In that case, the running processes will be terminated when the pbs_mom service is restarted.

Would it be feasible to not have an _exact_ comparison, but to allow for some clock skew to occur?

We have built from the 5.1-dev branch, on commit 71f6ede, see #322.

title: Fixed bug in high availability setup
body:
Fixed an incompatibility in the init script with high availability setup.

qterm would cause the active (listening) server to shutdown, which could be a remote server instead of the local server as expected.

Reverting the code to pre-4.1.3 behavior: Sending SIGTERM to local pbs_server instance, this would orderly shut down server process, regardless of HA / single master configuration.

title: If no arguments are given, qstat should still do something :)
body:
There are two loops
- one where it is checked if `optind >= argc`
- one where it was checked if `optind < argc`

The latter case caused qstat to not produce any output, even though there are queued jobs.

This PR changes that behaviour again and will also execute the loop in case there are no arguments.

title: replaced deprecated calls to interp->result
encode any text written to xml
body:
job attributes are not encoded when written to xml format. in particular, submitting jobs with `-V` can send lots of user-defined stuff, in particular exported functions (since heartbleed, 

``` bash
x () {
   echo ok
}
export -f x
```

generates a bash environment variable `BASH_FUNC_x` which contains the function code, which can contain lots of stuff like `&` and `>`.)

a lot of the code uses `xmlNewChild` which specifically states in http://xmlsoft.org/html/libxml-tree.html#xmlNewChild 

```
NOTE: @content is supposed to be a piece of XML CDATA, so it allows entity references. XML special chars must be escaped first by using xmlEncodeEntitiesReentrant(), or xmlNewTextChild() should be used.
```

title: .JB files for jobs submitted with qsub -V may be corrupt
body:
We've run into a problem where jobs submitted by particular users resulting in 'corrupt' `.JB` files when the user enabled `-V` to pass along the environment where the job was submitted from.

This resulting in SSH access to the workernodes where the job was running no longer working, which causes multi-node jobs to simply hang (because the MPI processes on the non-head nodes fail to start).

We saw error messages like this popping up in syslog:

```
015-08-12T22:12:23.473771+02:00 node436 pam_pbssimpleauth[25564]: opening /var/spool/pbs/mom_priv/jobs
2015-08-12T22:12:23.473800+02:00 node436 pam_pbssimpleauth[25564]: username example, known
2015-08-12T22:12:23.473808+02:00 node436 pam_pbssimpleauth[25564]: opening /var/spool/pbs/mom_priv/jobs/2795042.master.example.JB
2015-08-12T22:12:23.474277+02:00 node436 pam_pbssimpleauth[25564]: failed to read JB file in XML format: 
2015-08-12T22:12:23.474304+02:00 node436 pam_pbssimpleauth[25564]: trying to read JB file in binary format
2015-08-12T22:12:23.474311+02:00 node436 pam_pbssimpleauth[25564]: job file corrupt
2015-08-12T22:12:23.474319+02:00 node436 pam_pbssimpleauth[25564]: returning failed
```

The funny thing is that submitting jobs from an interactive job (`qsub -I`) _did_ work, so some small change in the environment seems to dance around this issue.
I took a close look at the difference in environment, but couldn't spot a likely suspect straight away (funky characters or whatever).

We're seeing this with:

```
$ qsub --version
Version: 5.1
Commit: 45b8fecdf60d392eff6209aefd1013a421988ec8
```

title: Torque 5.1 scheduler won't invoke FIFO scheduling
body:
Torque 5.1 won't employ FIFO scheduling even if 

strict_fifo: true ALL

is set in the sched_config file.

title: Fix for segfaults with newest nvidia drivers
body:
The latest nvidia drivers (346.59) generate substantially more output when nvidia-smi is called (all the supported clock rates are now listed).  The code for parsing the results of nvidia-smi used a fixed length (96000) byte buffer and did not check for buffer overflow.  This results in segmentation faults on systems with many GPUs running the latest drivers (which are required for TitanX cards).

The fix is to read in the nvidia-smi output into a dynamic string.  This has been minimally tested.

title: start the thread pool in the mom after creating it
body:
The mom contains all the code to create a thread pool, and a configuration setting 
`$thread_unlink_calls true`
will queue the `delete_job_files` call in the pool. However, the pool was never started and the function never ran.

title: remtree: don't skip files that start with two dots (exact match on '..')
body: The remtree() function recursively deletes files and directories, and skips over `.` and `..`. However, the code that matches `..` also matches file and directory names starting with `..` since there is no check for a terminating `\0`. The modified expression is also simplified by eliminating all the unnecessary parentheses; logic expressions evaluate left-to-right.

title: Failed to compile qstat.c with tcl8.6
body:
If tcl is enabled,  `make` stops with the following errors 

qstat.c: In function ‘void tcl_init()’:
qstat.c:2219:21: error: ‘Tcl_Interp’ has no member named ‘result’
             interp->result);
                     ^
qstat.c: In function ‘void tcl_run(int)’:
qstat.c:2348:23: error: ‘Tcl_Interp’ has no member named ‘result’
       trace = interp->result;
                       ^
qstat.c:2351:29: error: ‘Tcl_Interp’ has no member named ‘errorLine’
             script, interp->errorLine, trace);

The reason for this error is that interp->result/errorLine were deprecated in tcl8.5 and removed in the 8.6 version.

The workaround is to add 2 lines before #include <tcl.h>, which enables deprecated options
# if TCL_QSTAT

+#define USE_INTERP_RESULT 
+#define USE_INTERP_ERRORLINE
# include <sys/stat.h>
# include <tcl.h>

The similar problem is also appears in tcl scheduler.

title: Changed .spec-file to allow building RPMs with custom trqauthd-sock-dir
body:
As discussed on torquedev mailing list; this patch to the torque.spec allows building of Torque RPM's with a custom trqauthd-sock-dir.

It defines a variables to be specified via the command line:
rpmbuild -ba --define 'trqauthd_sock_dir /var/run' ./torque.spec

This in turn results in rpmbuild calling configure appropriately:
./configure --with-trqauthd-sock-dir=/var/run

If not defined it will default back to /tmp

title: job with after dependency gets removed when at end of depending job
body:
using torque 5.1-dev (with https://github.com/adaptivecomputing/torque/commit/2850e30c1d242c6804fef1cc2eb25108cbcdc600), we have the following behaviour, which i suspect is a bug:

a. qsub job_sleep100.sh -> jobid 1
b. qsub -W after:1 job_sleep500.sh -> jobid 2

job 1 and job 2 start (2 after 1 is started), when job 1 is finished, job 2 gets deleted/removed.

we expect from the description in the manual however that the after dependency only has influence on the start of job 2.

title: pbs_mom daemons should write the parent pid to file
body:
It's not easy to determine if a pbs_mom service running, because pbs_mom can spawn multiple instances of the pbs_mom process.
This makes it hard to check if the service is alive (see e.g. #288 )  

It would be beneficial if pbs_mom would write the parent (or whatever the service process is called) wites its pid to a file (eg. the `mom.lock` or another file).

title: Enable silent compilation option
body:
This patch enables silent compilation option.

When configured using `configure --enable-silent-rules` the compilation will switch to silent mode producing much more readable output that makes compilation warnings and errors much more noticeable.

More information here: https://autotools.io/automake/silent.html

title: Enable silent compilation (autotools)
body:
Silent compilation produces a more human readable compilation output, for an example see: https://autotools.io/automake/silent.html

Add:
`m4_ifdef([AM_SILENT_RULES], [AM_SILENT_RULES])`

after the `AC_INIT` directive in `configure.ac`

When `configure` is called with `--enable-silent-rules`, it will set the compilation to silent mode by default. Verbose compilation can still be manually requested through `make V=1` even when silent rules are configured.

title: Licensing and Debian
body:
So I gathered from [Debian Bug 641484 ](https://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=641484) that there is still an unresolved licensing conflict that prohibits Torque 2.5+ to be packaged for Debian, is that correct?

I am wondering if it possible for Adaptivecomputing to simply switch to one of the many [DFSG compatible licenses](https://wiki.debian.org/DFSGLicenses) to avoid this issue and still retain attribution. Apparently the main issue is the [vague phrasing of Paragraph 3](https://lists.debian.org/debian-legal/2004/02/msg00160.html) (formerly 5).

Also I am curious why paragraph 5 is still present when the OpenPBS license dropped the same section together with paragprahs 1 and 2 in 2001. Furthermore there is probably a typo in the new paragraph 1 where `acknowledgment contained in paragraph 5` should probably be `acknowledgment contained in paragraph 4` instead.

title: Patch: Scheduling is not proper in a cluster with more than one node with more than one Intel MIC cards
Use pidof to make sure the correct pbs_mom process is identified
body:
The problem addressed is the following. Occasionally, we are seeing service pbs_mom restart hanging with momctl unable to connect to a running pbs_mom. We are on EL6/EL7, and the offending code is located in contrib/init.d/pbs_mom.in +36. 

The problem can be reproduced (on a RHEL based system):

```
# service pbs_mom start
Starting TORQUE Mom:                                       [  OK  ]
# echo $$ > /var/spool/pbs/mom_priv/mom.lock 
# pkill pbs_mom
# service pbs_mom stop
Shutting down TORQUE Mom: cannot connect to MOM on node 'localhost', errno=111 (Connection refused)
cannot connect to MOM on node 'localhost', errno=111 (Connection refused)
cannot connect to MOM on node 'localhost', errno=111 (Connection refused)
cannot connect to MOM on node 'localhost', errno=111 (Connection refused)
cannot connect to MOM on node 'localhost', errno=111 (Connection refused)

kill -0 $pid thinks there is a process with the given $pid (true), but it also assumes this is the pbs_mom process (false), and momctl cannot connect to it:

# momctl -d0
cannot connect to MOM on node 'localhost', errno=111 (Connection refused)
```

So basically any sanity check that wants to restart the pbs_mom service is causing it to hang.

title: Package tests with tarball
body:
As a distribution packager it's very nice to be able to run unittests that verify I haven't broken anything while performing said packaging.  I also have many users who like to run tests to make sure that their system build the package correctly and to verify my packaging.

Related to the fact that tests are not part of the distributed tarball, the configure scripts all cannot be regenerated (autogen.sh).  This means that I can't apply any patch which touches the build system which is pretty common when getting a package to conform to the distribution rule (install locations, using system libraries etc.)

Please readd the tests and anything else referred to by the autotools.

Torque qsub equivalent to SGE qsub -sync or LSF qsub -K
body: Both SGE and LSF have qsub options that cause the qsub command to wait until the job has completed before returning.  Some 3rd party pipeline applications make use of this feature, which makes porting them to Torque more difficult (it necessitates the use of a wrapper script that does the qsub and then polls the job using qstat in a loop until the job finishes).

body:
Both approaches are implemented (see details in the task comments):
1. First 4 commits: 6322bd4, d55bf28, d92600b and 137e509.
Don't set last timestamp to zero when status send needs to be forced. Adjust it's value to force immediate update sending instead: last status timestamp = time now - timestamp send interval.

Introduce a new global "force update" flag and don't touch the actual timestamps. In this case the timestamps values will always represent the actual timestamp and the flag will be set/cleared when needed.

title: Prologue exit 2 Does Not Report ERROR
body:
Seen in TORQUE 4.2.8 and 4.2.6.1

With a prologue and prologue.parallel set to only exit 2 for testing:

```
#!/bin/bash

exit 2
```

...running a single node job causes the job to re-queue after the prologue exit 2 as expected.  Unfortunately, no error message is shown in pbsnodes and consequently, Moab does not see the error and mark the node as Down as expected with the default setting of:

```
RMMSGIGNORE     FALSE
```

On the other hand, a multi-node jobs that kicks off prologue.parallel on sister nodes behaves as expected.  The jobs re-queues, pbsnodes shows the ERROR (for only sister nodes) and Moab marks the node as Down.  The mother superior running prologue still does not report an error, though.

```
n1
     state = free
     np = 4
     ntype = cluster
     status = rectime=1405958542,varattr=,jobs=,state=free,netload=2610510775,gres=,message=
ERROR: prolog/epilog failed,file: /var/spool/torque/mom_priv/prologue.parallel,exit: 2,nonze
ro p/e exit status,loadave=0.04,ncpus=4,physmem=6122160kb,availmem=5944972kb,totmem=6122160k
b,idletime=205107266,nusers=0,nsessions=0,uname=Linux n1 2.6.32-431.20.3.el6.656a0000.x86_64
 #1 SMP Fri Jun 20 04:00:53 EDT 2014 x86_64,opsys=linux
     mom_service_port = 15002
     mom_manager_port = 15003
```

Running strace on pbs_mom showed EAGAIN (Resource temporarily unavailable) messages on mother superior nodes after running prologue that did not occur on sister nodes after running prologue.parallel:  

```
34748 fcntl(8, F_GETFL)                 = 0x802 (flags O_RDWR|O_NONBLOCK)
34748 read(8, 0x7fffb6715d80, 65536)    = -1 EAGAIN (Resource temporarily unavailable)
34748 read(8, 0x7fffb6715d80, 65536)    = -1 EAGAIN (Resource temporarily unavailable)
34748 read(8, 0x7fffb6715d80, 65536)    = -1 EAGAIN (Resource temporarily unavailable)
34748 read(8, 0x7fffb6715d80, 65536)    = -1 EAGAIN (Resource temporarily unavailable)
34748 read(8, 0x7fffb6715d80, 65536)    = -1 EAGAIN (Resource temporarily unavailable)
34748 read(8, 0x7fffb6715d80, 65536)    = -1 EAGAIN (Resource temporarily unavailable)

34748 read(8, 0x7fffb6715d80, 65536)    = -1 EAGAIN (Resource temporarily unavailable)
```

I hope this helps!

copy-back of stdout/err fails if "qsub -d some_dir" used
body:
If I specify "#PBS -d some_directory", at the end of the job Torque attempts to copy the stdout and stderr files from some_directory/.pbs_spool instead of $HOME/.pbs_spool.

This fails, because the stdout and stderr files are in $HOME/.pbs_spool

A somewhat ugly workaround is to create a soft-link from $HOME/.pbs_spool to some_directory/.pbs_spool. Adding the following to the job script works: (but does not clean up the link after the job is finished)

if [ ! -z $PBS_O_INITDIR ]; then
  ln -s ${HOME}/.pbs_spool ${PBS_O_INITDIR}/
fi 

cheers,

Steve

title: Munge auth: credential filename uniqueness, improved error logging
body:
- Use mkstemp() to create the temporary credential file instead of
  using a filename based upon timestamps.  This solves the problem of 
  munge auth failures due to the credential filenames not being unique.
- Make daughter routines of req_altauthenuser() return PBSE_\* codes.
  Replace req_reject() calls in these routines with log_err() calls
  using the aforementioned PBSE codes.  Add log_err() calls in these
  routines for additional error conditions for complete coverage, so
  we can actually tell from the server log what exactly went wrong if
  a munge auth attempt failed.  Call req_reject() once in
  req_altauthenuser() instead.
- Use non-blocking I/O for reading the munge credential in
  pipe_and_read_unmunge().
- Don't delete the credential file if there was a problem unmunge-ing
  the request.

title: pbsnodes not showing state per docs or listings in pbsnodes.c
body:
Just moving this one over from bugzilla. Bug 120 from awhile ago...

Brian Andrus 2011-04-11 11:12:09 MDT
From the pbsnodes man page:

```
   -l             List  node  names  and  their  state.  If no state is
```

specified, only nodes in the DOWN, OFFLINE, or UNKNOWN states are
                      listed.  Specifying a state string acts as an output
filter.   Valid  state  strings  are  "free",  "offline",  "down",
                      "reserve", "job-exclusive", "job-sharing", "busy",
"time-shared", or "state-unknown".

But:

[root@hamming2 log]# pbsnodes -l reserve
pbsnodes: Unknown node  MSG=cannot locate specified node
[root@hamming2 log]# pbsnodes -l state-unknown
pbsnodes: Unknown node  MSG=cannot locate specified node
[root@hamming2 log]# pbsnodes -l job-exclusive
pbsnodes: Unknown node  MSG=cannot locate specified node
[root@hamming2 log]# pbsnodes -l job-sharing
pbsnodes: Unknown node  MSG=cannot locate specified node
[root@hamming2 log]# pbsnodes -l time-shared
pbsnodes: Unknown node  MSG=cannot locate specified node

Seems to work for "free",  "offline",  "down", "busy"

I also see why, from pbsnodes.c:

const char *NState[] =
  {
  "NONE",
  "active",
  "all",
  "busy",
  "down",
  "free",
  "offline",
  "unknown",
  "up",
  NULL
  };

Maybe add the missing or update man page?

title: torque and openssl
body:
Torque's configure script requires openssl: it terminates if either -lssl or -lcrypto are not found with:
error: TORQUE needs lib openssl-devel in order to build
However, as far as I can tell no openssl routines are used in Torque:
- the string "openssl" does not appear in any file other than configure. I.e., none of the openssl include files are used in torque since that would require a line
  #include <openssl/...h>
- I was able to relink libtorque.so.2.0.0 without -lcrypto -lssl and then was able to relink pbs_server, pbs_mom and trqauthd with that library and without -lcrypto -lssl. No unresolved symbols were found and the resulting binaries run without problem.
  Thus, apparently openssl is not used at all.

title: pbs_mom init scripts use the pbs_mom lock file as pid file
body:
When an interactive job is running, multiple pbs_mom children are spawned. If the parent pbs_mom fails or is killed (eg during service restart), service start fails because the child pbs_moms are seen as active pbs_mom parent process.
Using the lock file that contains the pid to check the status fixes this problem. 

remark: i have no clue when `status -p <pidfile>` was introduced in the init functions (it's available in at least EL5.8 and EL6.4).

title: procs no longer parsed by Torque
body:
When the procs resource was originally introduced it was pass-through to the scheduler only.  Torque simply recorded the value for procs in Resources_List.  In Torque 2.5.0,  Torque would allocate x processors packed on any available node which allowed pbs_sched, Maui, and qrun to work as expected with jobs that request the procs resource. 

It appears that there has been a regression,  procs is again pass-through only in Torque 4.2

title: Add build dependencies
body: These are dependencies that are required when building torque RPMs for RHEL in a minimal environment (e.g. with mock)

title: Allow building of RPMs from git archive output
body:
This patch allows rpmbuild to make RPMs for RHEL6 using the torque.spec file from the repo, by:
1) Adding a call to autogen.sh before %configure macro
2) Adding BuildRequires for the autogen.sh script and the Torque binaries

Tested on FC19 by cloning the repo, building the .spec file with "./autogen.sh && configure", then using the .spec file and the git archive artefact to build the SRPM ("rpmbuild -bs torque.spec"), then using mock to build the SRPM into the RPMs in a RHEL6 environment.

title: node_check_script with node_check_interval=jobstart only executed on first node

we have in our mom_priv/config

```

```

I would expect the jobstart-nodecheck to be run at/before jobstart on EVERY node of the job. However, the health-chck script is only executed on the first node of a multi-node job, i.e. only on the node with the Mother Superior. This problems exists in both, torque-2.5.12 and torque-4.2.5/4.2.6.

title: Prevent sendmail hangs due to unclosed pipes
body: The problem was that multiple threads sending mail at the same time would "share" their pipes with _all_ the children being forked.  This ensures _all_ file descriptors (except the read pipe) is closed, including the log file and network connections.

title: torque incorrectly reports memory usage
Fix unit tests as of 20131024
Make sending e-mail more robust
body:
- Use pipes instead of temporary files to pass the content to sendmail
- Use comma as a delimiter for 'To:' addresses per RFC2822
- exec-like functions expect the first argument to be the name of the program
- Provide multiple addresses to sendmail in separate arguments
- Update the unit test to write to a temp file so it can check the content

title: torque 4.2 run-time option to disable cpuset
body:
pbs_mom run-time option so pbs_mom could be start without
      setting up cpuset if so desired by the system admin.

  /dev/cpuset/cpus - cpusets not configured/enabled on host


  Unfortunately the torque.4.2.4 does indeed mount it so that's
  not an option any longer.
```

title: Fixed escaping of the special characters in the environment variables
body:
When I create simple script

``` sh
cat > testenv.sh <<EOF
#!/bin/sh
echo $TESTENV
EOF
```

and submit batch job with torque-4.2.4.2 qsub command

``` sh
TESTENV="first,second" qsub -q queue@torque -v TESTENV testenv.sh
```

than I'm getting only "first" in job standard output. I think this behavior is caused by missing copy_env_value function. This function escapes special characters that comes from environment variables (copy_env_value was used in the past, e.g. in torque 2.5.x qsub sources).

title: TRQ-2289 - Queues disappeared
body:
- Make sure to check the return code of close() calls

Some file systems (particularly NFS) do not report errors until the close()
- Change to rename() instead of unlink(), link(), and unlink()

Renames should be atomic, but a server crash between the first unlink() and the link() will prevent the server from coming up correctly.

title: Changed hardcoded string lengths to strlen("...") for clarity.
body: Strings being checked are still hard-coded but this makes the code clearer and reduces the chance of an error being made through missing a "magic number" change if the argument string being checked is changed for any reason.

title: Resurrect accounting information at job end records
body:
USESAVEDRESOURCES governs if we will take consumed resources from the
saved information inside the job itself, but consumed resources from
job obituary request must be used unconditionally.

This is a regression from
  https://github.com/adaptivecomputing/torque/commit/dbbe2f966a744dbe1bb10d1cebaa5ec5feaed9cd
where blindly fixing GCC warnings resulted in functionality loss.

Patch is available,
  http://computing.kiae.ru/~rea/torque-2.5.13-resurrect-accounting-information-in-job-end-records.patch

It is now being tested on our Torque farm and shown no problems up to date, while resources_used.\* records reappeared in accounting and server logs.

title: huge address space usage of torque server
body:
torque_server uses about 900GB of address space on a system with about 2000 jobs (1600 running, 400 queued):
S USER       PID  PPID  NI   RSS  VSZ STIME %CPU     TIME COMMAND

After a restart vm usage almost instantly jumps to 500GB and then grows to 700GB within a minute or so. After that it grows more gradually to the value shown above and from there on the vm usage remains constant. title: pbs_sched stopped working
body:
This issue was reported by multiple community members and Matt Ezell points out that commit 062443f9b826bce01c400acd72c779c806764198 broke pbs_sched as it writes back on the same port.

Probably the best solution would be to add a variable called using_pbs_sched or something like that which specifies that the server not close this socket if pbs_sched is being used. This socket gets closed by default because the most popular schedulers that interface with TORQUE never write replies on this socket, making this pure overhead for most users.

title: TRQ-2250 Avoid trqauthd aborts
body:
trqauthd does not handle SIGPIPE so a buggy/rogue client could
cause it to abort. Also, the new feature to shut down trqauthd
does not verify that the request comes from root.  These two
flaws could allow a denial of service attack.

title: Fixed pam_pbssimpleauth.c to accept jobdir=<jobdir>
body:
If 'jobdir' is specified in pam configuration, pam_pbssimpleauth.c previously copied the string 'jobdir' over the compile-time default value of PBS_SERVER_HOME '/mom_priv/jobs'.

This change fixes it to copy the path part of a 'jobdir=<path to jobs>' pam configuration option in, for example, /etc/pam.d/password-auth, of the form:

account     required      pam_pbssimpleauth.so jobdir=/var/spool/torque/mom_priv/jobs

title: Allow mail_from to also use a name
body:
I notice that the name used for 'mail_from' seems to be 'root' no matter what the settings of the parameter. I suspect it probably pulls the name from the user pbs_server is running under.

By this I mean I can set mail_from to 'me@home.com' and it will show as from 'root' (although the from address is indeed me@home.com).

I know torque is using a sendmail command line of the nature:
        /usr/sbin/sendmail -f adm@my.domain job_owner@mail_domain.com

What I am looking for is a setting for the '-F' parameter from sendmail:
        /usr/sbin/sendmail -F 'Cluster Administrator' -f adm@my.domain job_owner@mail_domain.com

Could this be added? Users get confused when their status emails come from 'root'

title: pbs_server_attributes man page not up to date
body: I have noticed that the pbs_server_attributes man page does not contain all of the defined pbs_server attributes.  For example, none of the attributes relating to logging job information (record_job_info, record_job_script, etc) are documented in the man page.  I believe these attributes were added a number of years ago in Torque 2.5.  I'm sure there are other missing attributes, and there are probably queue attributes missing as well.

title: custom message in mail sent after job completion
body:
Is there any way in which a custom message can be included in the mail body of the mail that is sent after a job is completed?

E.g., I would imagine that setting an environment variable that reports the result of some test after the task in the job was completed would be very useful:

``` bash
export PBS_MAIL_MSG="Job done, results have been verified."
```

title: Update disrsi_.c
body: Introduced an earlier check on the count variable. The existing code checks this too late, in earlier Torque versions this can result in a buffer overflow - although this may not be the case in 4.x due to other code changes, best to play it safe.

title: Update disrsi_.c
body: Introduced an earlier check on the count variable. The existing code checks this too late and so can result in a buffer overflow.

title: Fix logic for parsing port number out of string (Issue #169)
body:
New logic is: 
1. If the string starts with a colon, it must be port number only.
2. If the string consists ENTIRELY of digits, and it converts to a
   valid TCP/UDP port number, assume it's only a port number.
3. Otherwise, parse it as a hostname with a possible ":port" suffix.

title: incorrect parsing in get_port in pbsd_main.c
body: get_port in pbsd_main.c checks if (isdigit(*arg)). If you specify an IP address for the host name or if the first character of the host name is a digit it will attempt to set the port number to the host's IP address instead.

title: sync 4.1-dev branch with 4.1.6.h2 branch
body:
While studying the changes in the various 4.1.6 branches, we noticed that some changes present in the `4.1.6.h2` branch were not included in the `4.1-dev` branch.
The naming scheme of the branches suggests that `4.1-dev` is (always) the latest and greatest of version `4.1.x`, while `4.1.6.h2` is bug fixes on top of the `4.1.6` release.

This PR syncs `4.1-dev` with `4.1.6.h2` by including commits that are present in `4.1.6.h2` but not in `4.1-dev` (including an important segfault fix). The commits that are not in `4.1.6.h2` are considered to be deliberately only in `4.1-dev`.

If I'm misunderstanding the branching scheme, feel free to simply close this PR again. If that's the case, where can we find more info on the branching scheme and the intention of the various branches?

title: Set trqauthd to connect to all valid addresses/protocols
body:
Modifies trq_simple_connect() so it tries all entries returned by
getaddrinfo() instead of giving up if the connection fails. For example,
given an /etc/hosts of:
127.0.0.1 localhost
::1       localhost

trqauthd will now try both the IPv6 and IPv4 addresses.

Previously, if getaddrinfo() returned the IPv6 address first and
pbs_server wasn't listening on this address, then trqauthd would
not try to connect to the IPv4 address.

title: fix a segfault caused by stack overflow in handle_stageout
body:
We met a segment fault when we submit a 'big' job to the cluster, such as 100 nodes \* 25 ppn，when the submitter has no write permission to the current directory, then after the job is done, the job log can not be transferred back because of lack of permission, in which case the pbs_server segment fault.

Even though we meet this problem in torque 4.1.3, I noticed the latest code in upstream that the same problem may also exist.

The error is caused by stack overflow that the log_buf in handle_stageout() allocates a little big chunk of memory in stack which causes the stack overflow, this patch can fix this

title: inconsistent used time reported in 'qstat -a'
body:
I'm seeing some strange used CPU/walltime reports when using `qstat -a` with Torque v4.1.6.

```
gengar1:~$ qstat 4100326
Job ID                    Name             User            Time Use S Queue
------------------------- ---------------- --------------- -------- - -----
4100326.master             Po2_Diss_CCSD    username        152:53:3 R long           
```

```
$ qstat 4100326 -a

master.gengar.gent.vsc: 
                                                                               Req'd    Req'd       Elap
Job ID               Username    Queue    Jobname          SessID NDS   TSK    Memory   Time    S   Time
-------------------- ----------- -------- ---------------- ------ ----- ------ ------ --------- - ---------
4100326.master.g     username    long     myjob           17727     1      8    --   71:59:00  R  00:33:05

```

```
$ qstat -f 4100326 | grep walltime
    resources_used.walltime = 41:32:11
    Resource_List.walltime = 71:59:00
```

The "Elapsed time" of ~33m makes no sense at all, since the job has been running full speed for 41+ hours, as indicated by the CPU time (it's a multi-threaded job).

What is the "Elapsed time" supposed to be representing? It's not walltime or CPU time (the documentation isn't exactly clear what is supposed to be showed with `-a`), but then what does it show?

title: ghost jobs in torque 2.5.x
body:
Dear All,

We have observed strange behaviour when using jobs with stagein options.

It happens when:
1. moab wants to start job on host X
2. moab issues AsyncJobStart request to pbs_server with X as exec_host
3. pbs_server sets exec_host for a job and tries to start it
4. connection to mom on port 150002 fails (due to connection refused error)
5. jobs stay in Q state but have exec_host set
6. pbsnodes shows that job has been allocated cpu on the host X but it is not running
7. moab considers the job as not running and tries to start it again

As a result it may happen that pbsnodes -a X indicates two cpus allocated for the job and
job is really running on host Y.

Well known symptom you all may have seen looks like that:

06/11/2013 00:00:13;0080;PBS_Server;Req;req_reject;Reject reply code=15046(Resource temporarily unavailable REJHOST=n1074-amd.zeus MSG=cannot allocate node 'n1074-amd.zeus' to job - node not currently available (nps needed/free: 1/0, gpus needed/free: 0/0, joblist: 32022181.batch... type=AsyncRunJob, from root@batch

As the result we see many jobslots which are blocked by such kind of a ghost jobs.

Log extract for the first failure
06/11/2013 00:13:59;0004;PBS_Server;Svr;svr_connect;attempting connect to host 10.10.4.83 port 15002
06/11/2013 00:13:59;0100;PBS_Server;Req;;Type AsyncRunJob request received from root@batch, sock=13
06/11/2013 00:13:59;0040;PBS_Server;Req;set_nodes;allocating nodes for job 32026672.batch.grid.cyf-kr.edu.pl with node expression 'n1103-amd.zeus'
06/11/2013 00:13:59;0040;PBS_Server;Req;set_nodes;job 32026672.batch allocated 1 nodes (nodelist=n1103-amd.zeus/52)
06/11/2013 00:13:59;0008;PBS_Server;Job;32026672.batch;Job Run at request of root@batch
06/11/2013 00:13:59;0004;PBS_Server;Svr;svr_connect;attempting connect to host 10.10.4.83 port 15002
06/11/2013 00:13:59;0004;PBS_Server;Svr;svr_connect;cannot connect to host port 15002 - cannot establish connection () - time=0 seconds
06/11/2013 00:13:59;0001;PBS_Server;Req;;Server could not connect to MOM

I am trying to diagnose it but any help is very appreciated
## Best Regards

Lukasz Flis

title: Libnet:  remove unused header

title: Handle condition of invalid submit filter more gracefully.
body:
Trying this again!

While tracking down a very obscure issue with qsub (there's a list of about 15 requirements to reproduce) I found that the PBS_O_SUBMIT_FILTER was being checked for validity but nothing was actually being done with the results of said check. I may file an issue about the obscure issue if I can get some more data points, but essentially the PBS_O_SUBMIT_FILTER gets lost and ends up as a null string. This produces some mystical errors when trying to submit a job.

This change probably isn't super useful, but this would have given us a head start on where to look for the cause of the mystical errors. I can see the argument that invalid filters may be fairly obvious ("sh: /invalid/submit/filter: not found") on run time but that doesn't seem very graceful. Why bother stat()'ing the filter in validate_submit_filter() if the results aren't being acted on?

This is my first time jumping into torque code so this may not be the best way to code this :)

Fix pesky 'Non-digit found where a digit was expected' errors
body:
Copying new data into the DIS buffer didn't NULL-terminate the
string (because it's not actually the end of the string, so why
would it?).  The problem comes if the new data exceeds the buffer
size: it uses snprintf with "%s%s" to copy the old and new data
into the new buffer.  Since the old data isn't NULL-terminated,
you will get bogus data in the middle of your new buffer.

Note: this fix is to just set the EOD pointer to NULL.  Alternatively, one could swap the memcpy with a snprintf using length *read_len +1.

title: Have qstat request specific attributes
body:
This request has three commits:
- Fix 'qstat -u <username>' which was recently broken when support was added for 'qstat -f -u <username>'
- Request specific attributes from qstat to avoid unnecessary network traffic (changes only in qstat.c)
- Add a new batch request type SelStatAttr to allow status requests specify an attropl and an attrl to both filter and specify which attributes need to be returned.  qstat will fall back to SelStat if SelStatAttr is not supported on the server

In aggregate, this will significantly reduce the amount of data over the wire, especially on large systems (since the exec_host list can be a couple MB).

I'm very comfortable with the first commit and fairly comfortable with the second.  The third is a little outside of my comfort zone, so please review it carefully and let me know if there are any suggested changes.

title: /dev/null as stdout/stderr destination not always handled properly
body:
I have found a problem with how TORQUE handles /dev/null as a destination for a stderr/stdout spool file under certain circumstances. 

submit_host:/dev/null (remote) works fine -- pbs_mom does not attempt to scp the file if the destination is /dev/null on the remote system, and everything works as expected

/dev/null does not (local destination)  pbs_mom seems to send the output to /dev/null (the file is never created in server_priv/spool) but then it still tries to copy the .ER file from the spool directory to /dev/null when the job finishes.  We get emails with these error messages:

Unable to copy file /var/spool/torque/spool/277828.host.domain.ER to /dev/null
**\* error from copy
/bin/cp: cannot stat `/var/spool/torque/spool/277828.host.domain.ER': No such file or directory
**\* end error output

We never noticed this with qsub, because if I do "qsub -e /dev/null ..." qsub will prepend the submit host, so what is actually passed to TORQUE is submit_host:/dev/null.  However, we also use the pbs_python API and do not bother prepending out submit host to the e and o job parameters because we want to do all local copies anyway.

This is with TORQUE 4.2.0

title: Fix retry logic when PBSAPITIMEOUT is set
body:
Previously, when PBSAPITIMEOUT was set, failures were not correctly
reported.  The functions would move on to DIS and then get end-of-
file messages:
$ PBSAPITIMEOUT=3 /opt/torque/default/bin/qstat @down-server
qstat: End of File

Now, it properly handles bad return codes and gives a useful
message:
$ PBSAPITIMEOUT=3 /opt/torque/default/bin/qstat @down-server
Error communicating with down-server(192.168.1.10)
Communication failure.
qstat: cannot connect to server down-server (errno=15085) Time out

This probably needs to be merged into master, 4.2-dev, and 4.1-dev

title: Travis-ci initial configuration and parallel build
body:
@mattaezell writes:

> Is the intention to just do builds or builds and unit tests?  As currently
> configured, the 'make check' doesn't actually do anything.  You have to
> configure --with-check for it to actually execute the unit tests.
> 
> Also, I noticed that the Travis Vms are configured with 1.5 cores (what's
> half a core??).  Anyway, it would probably make sense to specify make's
> parallel option '-j' of at least 2.  I've noticed that oversubscribing
> cores can sometimes yield improvement, when some are doing disk I/O and
> others are using the CPU.  On my desktop with 2 cores, a very simple
> non-scientific test resulted in 'make -j1 && make -j1 check' taking
> 5:02.014, -j2 taking 3:27.915 and -j4 taking 3:14.099.
> 
> No builds have run yet - I think someone from Adaptive has to login to
> Travis to enable the builds.

title: Travis ci integration
body:
This request contains configuration data for travis-ci.org. Travis-ci is a continuous build system which is integrated into github (i.e. it'll tell you if unmerged pending pull requests will break the build if they're merged in).

If this patch is acceptable, the owner of the adaptivecomputing/torque repository needs to login to http://travis-ci.org/ and turn the repository "on" using the settings page before future commits will be automatically built on travis-ci.org.

After the master branch is working with continuous integration, it might be a good idea to continuously build other branches as well (via the .travis.yml file).

title: Adding server option to disable Cray reservation orphan cleanup
body:
We are currently having some issues with orphan reservation cleanup being too aggressive.  There may also be use cases where admins want to setup ALPS reservations that aren't managed by TORQUE.

This patch doesn't change the default (on), but it adds a new server parameter 'cray_orphan_cleanup'.

title: PBS_NODEFILE is missing for interactive jobs on 4.2.1
body:
I just made a quick stab at torque 4.2.1 for my work on torque-roll for Rocks and found that the nodefile is missing on the nodes when you run an interactive job.  Non-interactive jobs seems to work fine. Here is a quick run-through:

Regular jobs are fine

```
[marve@hpc1 ~]$ echo cat \$PBS_NODEFILE | qsub -lnodes=2:ppn=2,walltime=1000
8.hpc1.local
[marve@hpc1 ~]$ cat STDIN.o8
compute-0-2
compute-0-2
compute-0-1
compute-0-1
```

Interactive jobs are not

```
[marve@hpc1 ~]$ qsub -lnodes=2:ppn=2,walltime=1000 -I
qsub: waiting for job 9.hpc1.local to start
qsub: job 9.hpc1.local ready

[marve@compute-0-2 ~]$ echo $PBS_NODEFILE
/var/spool/torque/aux//9.hpc1.local
[marve@compute-0-2 ~]$ ll /var/spool/torque/aux/
total 0
```

This is kind of serious for the torque roll setup because I have a hack that integrates the standard openmpi (that do not contain libtm support) with torque and it depends on having the nodefile available.

```
[marve@compute-0-2 ~]$ cat /opt/torque/etc/openmpi-setup.sh 
export OMPI_MCA_orte_rsh_agent="pbsdshwrapper"
export OMPI_MCA_orte_default_hostfile=$PBS_NODEFILE
export OMPI_MCA_orte_leave_session_attached=1
```

And it barfs on me when the nodefile is missing

```
[marve@compute-0-2 ~]$ source /opt/torque/etc/openmpi-setup.sh 
[marve@compute-0-2 ~]$ mpirun ./hello.x
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Open RTE was unable to open the hostfile:
    /var/spool/torque/aux//9.hpc1.local
Check to make sure the path and filename are correct.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
[compute-0-2.local:02832] [[3496,0],0] ORTE_ERROR_LOG: Not found in file base/ras_base_allocate.c at line 247
[compute-0-2.local:02832] [[3496,0],0] ORTE_ERROR_LOG: Not found in file base/plm_base_launch_support.c at line 99
[compute-0-2.local:02832] [[3496,0],0] ORTE_ERROR_LOG: Not found in file plm_rsh_module.c at line 1167
```

title: 4.2.x : Add --enable-mic (Intel Phi) flag to torque.spec.in
body:
Hi, I hope this is correct :) we needed to add Phi support to our test cluster running torque-4.2.x but it appeared it not being passed through via the rpmbuild command. The following very simple diff patch to the buildutils/torque.spec.in for torque-4.2.1 appears to work for us : 
--- buildutils/torque.spec.orig 2013-03-10 14:53:25.532000584 +0000
+++ buildutils/torque.spec.in   2013-03-10 14:59:06.667998157 +0000
@@ -25,6 +25,7 @@
 %bcond_with    numa
 %bcond_with    pam
 %bcond_with    top
+%bcond_with    mic

 ### Features enabled by default
 %bcond_without scp
@@ -46,6 +47,7 @@
 %define ac_with_scp        --with-rcp=%{?with_scp:scp}%{!?with_scp:pbs_rcp}
 %define ac_with_spool      --%{?with_spool:en}%{!?with_spool:dis}able-spool
 %define ac_with_syslog     --%{?with_syslog:en}%{!?with_syslog:dis}able-syslog
+%define ac_with_mic        --%{?with_mic:en}%{!?with_mic:dis}able-mic

 ### Build Requirements
 %define breq_gui   %{?with_gui:tcl-devel tk-devel tclx}
I haven't coded up the -with-mic-path because we have used the default location so I will add that later if needed. Best Regards Mark Roberts

title: Sync it backwards
4.2 dev
Check the return value of close() to prevent data loss
body:
When updating the serverdb file or job files, pbs_server will write the
new data out to a temporary file and then overwrite the original.  In
some cases (ENOSPC over NFS, for example), write errors may not show up
until the file is closed.  In this case, keep the old file around (old
data is usually better than data loss).

title: pbs_mom: added support for process oom-killer tunables in Linux
body:
Two new mom config variables have been added: 
   'job_oom_score_adjust'
   'mom_oom_immunize'. 

Both settings are linux-specific therefore implemented only in linux/mom_mach.c

First one sets /proc/<pid>/oom_adj for every spawned task according to configuration
Tested with single task jobs and with mpiexec, pbsdsh multi-task jobs

Second one prevents pbs_mom from being incidentally hit by oom killer.
Due to the oom_score scoring algorithm in EL5 pbs_mom is usually first process to be hit by oom killer - this variable prevents that unnecessary act of violence.
